commander.name: Major-General Francis Tuker
commander.previous_service: Assumed command December 1941, led division through North Africa campaign from Gazala to Tunisia

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia - Mareth Line sector, Southern Tunisia front

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.note: Three field regiments fully equipped - 2nd, 11th, 31st Field Regiments

supply_logistics.supply_status: STRAINED - Extended supply lines from Tripoli (captured Jan 23, 1943) through Libyan Desert to Tunisia front. Division advancing into Tunisia after 1800km pursuit from El Alamein. Supply dependent on coastal road and limited port capacity at Tripoli. Fuel and ammunition adequate for defensive operations, constrained for offensive operations.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Southern Tunisia - Mareth Line sector. Mix of coastal plain, rocky hills, and Matmata Hills. More varied terrain than Western Desert with some vegetation.

subordinate_units.note: Veteran brigade - continuous combat since Operation Compass 1940
Reunited with division October 1942, fought at El Alamein and pursuit to Tunisia
Reformed brigade rejoined division December 1942 after original 11th Brigade lost at Tobruk June 1942

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry division operating in mountainous terrain of southern Tunisia. Assigned to XXX Corps for operations against Axis Mareth Line defenses. Mission: Attack prepared defensive positions in broken terrain unsuitable for armor-heavy operations. Mountain warfare training relevant to Matmata Hills operations.
special_capabilities: Elite veteran division - continuous combat experience since Operation Compass 1940
Mountain warfare expertise (from Indian Army training) applicable to Matmata Hills
Experienced in combined arms operations with armor support
Strong performance in night operations and infiltration tactics
Multi-ethnic composition (British, Indian, Gurkha battalions) with proven cohesion
tactical_innovations: Adaptation of mountain warfare tactics to Tunisian hill country
Integration of reformed 11th Brigade executed smoothly
Night infiltration tactics developed during El Alamein battles
Coordination with French forces on southern flank
known_issues: No organic armor - dependent on attached tank units
Reformed 11th Brigade still working up to division standards
Extended supply lines from Tripoli create logistical constraints
Transition from desert to more varied Tunisian terrain requires tactical adjustments
Increased air interdiction threat compared to Western Desert
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Veteran of North African desert warfare since 1940. Now adapting to more varied Tunisian terrain with hills, vegetation, and seasonal rainfall. Mountain warfare skills increasingly relevant. Water discipline and vehicle maintenance expertise remain valuable.

scenario_suitability: Battle of Mareth (March 20-27, 1943) - Frontal assault on fortifications
special_rules: Desert warfare veteran bonus (+2 in desert/arid terrain)
Night operations bonus (experienced in infiltration tactics)
Multi-ethnic unit cohesion (no penalties for mixed composition)
Reformed brigade: 11th Brigade -1 effectiveness until Q2 1943
historical_engagements: East Africa Campaign (1941) - Keren, Amba Alagi
Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942)
Pursuit from El Alamein to Tunisia (Nov-Dec 1942)

source: Seed file: north_africa_seed_units_COMPLETE.json - 4th Indian Division 1943-Q1 confirmed
British Army Lists - Indian formations in Tunisia 1943
Tunisia Campaign order of battle - Mareth Line operations
Historical records - XXX Corps composition January-March 1943
required_field_gaps: exact personnel casualties from El Alamein pursuit

chief_of_staff.name.reason: Chief of Staff name not documented in available sources for 1943-Q1 Tunisia period
chief_of_staff.name.mitigation: Indian Army divisional staff records or 8th Army war diaries would contain this information

personnel_strength.reason: Exact personnel strength after El Alamein pursuit and brigade reorganization not found. Estimated based on Q4 1942 baseline (18,200) minus estimated casualties (~400) from pursuit operations.
personnel_strength.estimate_method: Q4 1942 strength (18,200) - estimated pursuit casualties (400) = 17,800 personnel. Reformed 11th Brigade at full strength but working up.

11th_brigade_reformation.reason: 11th Brigade reformation confirmed December 1942 but exact date and initial composition details incomplete. Brigade had been lost at Tobruk June 1942.
11th_brigade_reformation.mitigation: Indian Army brigade formation records would provide detailed reconstitution timeline and initial equipment state

notes: Q1 1943: Division in TUNISIA - Mareth Line sector, southern front
Major operations Q1 1943: Advance into Tunisia, Battle of Medenine (6 Mar), Battle of Mareth (20-27 Mar)
CRITICAL: 11th Brigade REFORMED December 1942 - new brigade replacing unit lost at Tobruk June 1942
161st Brigade departed December 1942 - temporary attachment ended
Equipment: Full complement of 6-pounder AT guns (transition from 2-pounders complete)
Supply challenges: Extended lines from Tripoli through Libyan Desert
Terrain transition: From Western Desert to Tunisian hills and coastal plain
Tier 2 classification due to estimated personnel and missing staff names
Extrapolated from Q4 1942 with Tunisia campaign adjustments
